G.L. c. 208, \u00a7\u00a7 28, 28A.proposition: NOW COMES Jessica Turner, the Plaintiff in the above-captioned matter, and files this Complaint for Modification of the custody order entered by this Court on March 15, 2018, pursuant to G.L. c. 208, §§ 28, 28A and applicable case law.

G.L. c. 209B, \u00a7 2.proposition: This Court has proper jurisdiction over this matter because the last custody order involving the parties and the minor child, dated March 15, 2018, was entered by this Court, pursuant to G.L. c. 209B, § 2.

G.L. c. 208, \u00a7 28.proposition: Pursuant to G.L. c. 208, § 28, this Court retains continuing jurisdiction to modify the prior custody order upon a showing of a material and substantial change in circumstances that affects the best interests of the minor child.

*Schechter v. Schechter*, 88 Mass. App..proposition: Massachusetts courts consistently hold that custody modifications require a showing of material and substantial changes that affect the best interests of the child.
*Schechter v. Schechter*, 88 Mass. App..support_reasoning: The opinion in Schechter discusses initial custody determinations and removal, focusing on the best interests standard and deference to the trial judge’s findings, but it does not address the standard for *modification* of an existing custody order. There is no language requiring a showing of a material and substantial change in circumstances as a prerequisite to modifying custody; the case is about affirming an original custody and visitation judgment with a 209A order. Thus it cannot be cited as authority for the specific proposition regarding custody *modifications* and material and substantial change.
*Schechter v. Schechter*, 88 Mass. App..relevant_excerpt:
“In this case, the judge made findings that the father was domineering in his relations with the mother and child. … The findings are amply supported by the evidence and demonstrate that the decision to suspend the father’s visitation rights with the child was based on the exercise of a sound discretion.”

“In Massachusetts the focus in a custody dispute between parents is not on their personal rights but on the welfare of the child. … [T]he overriding concern of the court must be the promotion of the best interests of the children and their general welfare.”

*Hunter v. Rose*, 463 Mass. 488 (2012).proposition: Massachusetts courts consistently hold that custody modifications require a showing of material and substantial changes that affect the best interests of the child.
*Hunter v. Rose*, 463 Mass. 488 (2012).support_reasoning: The opinion discusses the general best-interests standard for an initial custody determination between parents and the deference owed to the trial judge, but it does not frame the case as a *modification* of an existing custody order or apply a "material and substantial change in circumstances" test. The court instead applies the best-interests factors in the first instance, without articulating or relying on a changed-circumstances requirement. Thus, it is not authority for the specific proposition that custody modifications in Massachusetts require a showing of material and substantial changes affecting the child’s best interests.
*Hunter v. Rose*, 463 Mass. 488 (2012).relevant_excerpt: “Parents have an equal right to custody of their children. … ‘In custody matters, the touchstone inquiry [is] … what is ‘best for the child’…. The determination of which parent will promote a child’s best interests rests within the discretion of the judge … However, the judge must weigh ‘all relevant factors in determining the best interests of the child.’” (463 Mass. at 494).

*Dwyer v. Dwyer*, 71 Mass. App. Ct. 84 (.proposition: A significant improvement in a non-custodial parent’s ability to provide a stable, nurturing environment constitutes a material change in circumstances under Massachusetts law.
*Dwyer v. Dwyer*, 71 Mass. App. Ct. 84 (.support_reasoning: This opinion concerns a criminal conviction for failure to register as a sex offender and interprets the Massachusetts sex offender registration statute. It does not involve child custody, non-custodial parents, or standards for material change in circumstances under family law. Therefore, it provides no authority for the claimed proposition about improvements in a non-custodial parent’s home environment constituting a material change in circumstances.
*Dwyer v. Dwyer*, 71 Mass. App. Ct. 84 (.relevant_excerpt: The sex offender registration statute, G. L. c. 6, §§ 178C-178P, provides for the registration of sex offenders with the sex offender registry board ("SORB" or "board"). Section 178C defines "sex offender," as pertinent here, as "a person who resides ... in the commonwealth and who has been convicted of a sex offense." "Sex offense" is defined as any of the Massachusetts criminal statutes listed in § 178C, as well as "a like violation of the laws of another state . . . ." All sex offenders must participate in the board's initial, prehearing registration process.

*Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas*, 395 Mass..proposition: The child’s best interests, including emotional and psychological well-being, are paramount in custody determinations.
*Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas*, 395 Mass..support_reasoning: The opinion repeatedly emphasizes that the governing standard in custody and removal questions is the child’s “best interests” and expressly includes emotional and developmental needs as central. In articulating how to apply the removal statute, the court states that the effect on the child, including emotional and psychological well-being and the child’s relationship with both parents, is paramount. Thus, the case supports the proposition that the child’s best interests, including emotional and psychological welfare, are paramount in custody determinations.
*Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas*, 395 Mass..relevant_excerpt: “The words ‘upon cause shown’ mean only that removal must be in the best interests of the child … and thus the central question in this case is how these ‘best interests’ are to be determined. … An evaluation of the best interests of the child requires attention to whether the quality of the child’s life may be improved by the change … and the extent to which moving or not moving will affect the emotional, physical, or developmental needs of the child.”

*Mason v. Coleman*, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).proposition: The child’s best interests, including emotional and psychological well-being, are paramount in custody determinations.
*Mason v. Coleman*, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).support_reasoning: The opinion repeatedly states that removal and custody decisions under G.L. c. 208, § 30 turn on the children’s “best interests” and applies that standard by focusing on the children’s developmental, social, educational, and emotional needs. The court affirms that the judge properly weighed how relocation would affect the child’s socialization, education, and emotional well-being, and stresses that the State may restrict a parent’s relocation rights to promote the child’s best interests. This aligns with the proposition that the child’s best interests, including emotional and psychological well-being, are paramount in such determinations.
*Mason v. Coleman*, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).relevant_excerpt: “The words ‘upon cause shown’ mean only that removal must be in the best interests of the child. … ‘[T]he best interests of the child standard is one grounded in the particular needs and circumstances of the individual child in question.’ … The order is based on the judge’s findings that the children’s best interests would be negatively affected by this move. She made detailed written findings that their current schools were superior, that uprooting the children would be difficult for them, [and] that the move would impair the father’s parenting to the detriment of their interests….”

*Gilmore v. Gilmore*, 369 Mass. 598 (197.proposition: Courts consider the preferences of older children in custody determinations, particularly where such preferences align with stability and emotional needs.
*Gilmore v. Gilmore*, 369 Mass. 598 (197.support_reasoning: The opinion focuses on procedural and evidentiary issues in custody determinations—specifically, the right to cross-examine a guardian ad litem whose report is relied upon by the judge. It reiterates that the governing standard is the best interests of the child, but it does not discuss or give weight to the expressed preferences of older children, nor link such preferences to stability or emotional needs. Therefore it does not provide authority for the proposition regarding consideration of older children’s preferences.
*Gilmore v. Gilmore*, 369 Mass. 598 (197.relevant_excerpt: “We are mindful of the court’s need for assistance in arriving at a just resolution of custody cases. There is no question that court-appointed investigators can help a judge to determine what is in the best interests of a child, ‘[t]he governing principle by which the court must be guided.’ Hersey v. Hersey, 271 Mass. 545, 555 (1930).”

*Adoption of Hugo*, 428 Mass. 219 (1998).proposition: Courts consider the preferences of older children in custody determinations, particularly where such preferences align with stability and emotional needs.
*Adoption of Hugo*, 428 Mass. 219 (1998).support_reasoning: The opinion is about best-interests determinations in adoption/custody between a foster parent and an aunt for a very young child (age four and younger throughout the proceedings). It discusses stability, bonding, sibling relationships, and special needs, but it does not address considering the stated preferences or wishes of older children at all. Therefore, it does not support a proposition about judicial consideration of older children's custodial preferences.
*Adoption of Hugo*, 428 Mass. 219 (1998).relevant_excerpt: "Stability in the life of a child, especially one as young as Hugo, is important, as the judge himself recognized. Custody of Two Minors, 396 Mass. 610, 617 (1986). Here, the judge had to weigh the benefits of stability, of keeping Hugo in his present home, with moving him to a family where, in his judgment, it is more likely that Hugo will receive the home support, stability, and reinforcement of efforts to address his developmental needs so critical to his future development."

*Fort v. Fort*, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 411 (1.proposition: Evidence of a child’s emotional distress and bonding with a parent supports modifications of custody.
*Fort v. Fort*, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 411 (1.support_reasoning: The opinion concerns an initial custody award and whether a father’s cohabitation should preclude him from receiving custody, not a post-judgment modification based on a child’s emotional distress or bonding. The court focuses on comparing the parents’ temperaments and home environments and requires evidence of an adverse effect from the cohabiting relationship, but it does not discuss using evidence of a child’s emotional distress or bonding with a parent as a basis for modifying custody. Thus, it does not affirm the proposition that such evidence supports modifications of custody.
*Fort v. Fort*, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 411 (1.relevant_excerpt: “The master’s findings adopted by the judge in the case before us properly did not find relevant the moral or criminal character of the husband’s living arrangement in the absence of evidence showing an adverse effect on Edward. The determinative focus was on a specific comparison between the husband’s steady disposition and even temperament and the relative tranquility of his living arrangement, on the one hand, and the emotionally charged atmosphere often generated by the wife’s interaction with her family.”

*Loebel v. Loebel*, 77 Mass. App. Ct. 74.proposition: Evidence of a child’s emotional distress and bonding with a parent supports modifications of custody.
*Loebel v. Loebel*, 77 Mass. App. Ct. 74.support_reasoning: The opinion focuses on procedural error: the judge’s refusal to take updated evidence on remand when reassessing custody. While the court notes that best‑interests determinations may consider a wide range of evidence and that circumstances in the children’s lives had changed, it does not specifically discuss evidence of emotional distress or bonding as a basis for modifying custody, nor does it hold that such evidence supports modification. The case is about the need for a new evidentiary hearing and comprehensive best‑interests analysis, not about emotional distress/bonding as a distinct ground for custody modification.
*Loebel v. Loebel*, 77 Mass. App. Ct. 74.relevant_excerpt: “When determining child custody awards in general, or modifications of custody awards based on changed circumstances, the guiding principle always has been the best interests of the children. . . . Discretion allows the judge when determining the best interests of children, to consider the widest range of permissible evidence, including the reports and testimony of a court appointed investigator or G.A.L., evidence of the history of the relationship between the child and each parent, evidence of each parent’s present home environment and over-all fitness to further the child’s best interests….”

*Azia v. DiLasio*, 94 Mass. App. Ct. 596.proposition: Defendant’s unwillingness to engage in cooperative parenting also warrants modification.
*Azia v. DiLasio*, 94 Mass. App. Ct. 596.case_name: Clear Channel Outdoor, Inc. v. Zoning Board of Appeals of Salisbury
*Azia v. DiLasio*, 94 Mass. App. Ct. 596.support_reasoning: The opinion concerns zoning board decisions about special permits for competing billboard applications and the improper consideration of legally irrelevant factors. It does not involve family law, parenting issues, or standards for modification of custody or parenting orders. Therefore, it cannot be authority for the proposition that a defendant’s unwillingness to engage in cooperative parenting warrants modification.
*Azia v. DiLasio*, 94 Mass. App. Ct. 596.relevant_excerpt: "For the reasons set out above, we conclude that the board's decisions must be set aside because they rest on legally impermissible grounds."

G.L. c. 208, \u00a7 31.proposition: Good faith attempts to modify overly restrictive schedules are supported by Massachusetts public policy favoring the involvement of both parents in a child’s life.

G.L. c. 209C, \u00a7 10.proposition: Good faith attempts to modify overly restrictive schedules are supported by Massachusetts public policy favoring the involvement of both parents in a child’s life.
